channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Video of Violent Hazing in Paramilitary Unit Stirs Dismay in China
item.description: A leaked video shows members of the country’s People’s Armed Police beating new recruits, a glimpse of hazing rarely seen in China. The authorities apologized and promised an investigation.
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A video showing firefighters undergoing violent hazing has circulated widely online.

item.title: China Is Tied to Spying on European Diplomats
item.description: A report finds foreign ministries were the subject of computer breaches.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: Delay Foreseen in Removing Syrian Chemicals
item.description: The leader of the group helping oversee the destruction of Syria’s chemical arms said that meeting a Dec. 31 export deadline would be difficult.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Mayor Ousted in Colombia After Claims of Bungling
item.description: The Bogotá mayor, Gustavo Petro, was said to have made serious mistakes in his handling of the botched transfer of garbage collection from private contractors to a government-run service.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Mayor Gustavo Petro of Bogotá in 2012. He can appeal his dismissal.

item.title: Ukrainian Protesters Struggle to Keep Police and Cold at Bay
item.description: A confrontation at a tiny camp of Ukrainian protesters was an example of the seesaw struggle with the police for control of strategic areas in Kiev.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cooks prepared food at the camp in Independence Square in Kiev on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Looking on the Bright Side of Bad Air
item.description: The heavy air pollution covering much of eastern China recently has prompted intense coverage in the Chinese media, some of it humorous, showing that Chinese residents have a far better idea now of what they are breathing than they did just a few years ago, when such information was considered sensitive.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Searches for "air pollution" in China in recent years, according to Google.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China to End Loophole in Child Rape Law, Experts Say
item.description: A deeply unpopular law in China that effectively gave men having sex with under-14s lighter criminal punishments than those who committed rape will be abolished, according to lawyers.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Memo From the United Nations: Stopping Bloodshed in the Central African Republic Amid Ghosts of Genocide
item.description: United Nations diplomats search for a plan for keeping the nation from becoming another Rwanda or Bosnia.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: French soldiers on patrol on Monday in Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic, where Muslim rebel fighters have battled Christian militias.

item.title: World Briefing | United Nations: Nuclear Team to Visit Libya
item.description: An inspection team from the United Nations’ nuclear agency will visit Libya to assess the thousands of barrels of yellowcake uranium that reportedly are being stored at a former military site amid a “precarious” security situation in the country, a United Nations official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Without Notice, Putin Dissolves a News Agency
item.description: The decision to dissolve RIA Novosti, along with its international radio broadcaster, came as a complete surprise and signaled a major state media reorganization in Russia.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Looting Spreads as Police Officers Stage Strikes
item.description: Police officers in 14 of the country’s 23 provinces have staged work stoppages in recent days, local news media said.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Public Ouster in North Korea Unsettles China
item.description: As North Koreans watched the unusual spectacle of Jang Song-thaek’s arrest on television, Chinese leaders were concerned about the loss of one of their major links to the leadership of the North.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Jang Song-thaek, uncle to North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, was forcibly removed from a meeting of the Political Bureau by uniformed personnel in a photograph released Monday by Yonhap news agency.

item.title: After Mandela, a Test at the Polls for His Party
item.description: After the death of its most beloved leader, the African National Congress could face its most competitive elections since it came to power in 1994.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: Diepsloot, a settlement north of Johannesburg, where other parties have made inroads on the African National Congress.

item.title: Ukraine’s Forces Move Against Protesters, Dimming Hopes for Talks
item.description: Ominous new action by Ukraine’s security forces included a raid on an opposition party’s headquarters, as Western officials grasped for a way to defuse the country’s intensifying political crisis.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Soldiers on Monday blocked the way to Independence Square in Kiev, Ukraine.

item.title: German Coalition Hangs on a Vote by One Party
item.description: A deal by Chancellor Angela Merkel with her Social Democratic rivals for a coalition government must be approved by the party’s members, which some see as possibly unconstitutional.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: The Lede: Updates on Mourning for Mandela
item.description: The Lede continues to follow the global reaction to the death of Nelson Mandela, on a day of tributes to the man who led the emancipation of South Africa from white minority rule and then served as its first freely elected president.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Scores of Leaders Heading to South Africa for Service
item.description: The memorial will be held in the World Cup soccer stadium in Soweto, South Africa, where Nelson Mandela made his last public appearance in 2010.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Israel to Allow Building Materials Into Gaza
item.description: After an eight-week hiatus, construction materials will be allowed in again starting Tuesday, but only for United Nations projects.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Navy Secretary Expands Review of Supply Contracts
item.description: Amid an inquiry into bribery in the Pacific, Secretary Ray Mabus has ordered an examination of how the service awards contracts around the globe.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER DREW and DANIELLE IVORY

item.title: A Rare Middle East Agreement, on Water
item.description: Israel, Jordan and the Palestinian Authority agreed to build a Red Sea-Dead Sea water project, including a brine pipeline and desalination plant, that is meant to benefit all three parties.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: The Lede: Ukraine on Edge as Protesters and the Authorities Face Off
item.description: Battalions of police officers confronted demonstrators in Kiev, a day after a huge rally in which a statue of Lenin was toppled in Independence Square.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Protests Continue in Thailand After Election Is Set
item.description: The move by Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra did not satisfy antigovernment demonstrators in Bangkok, who vowed to expel her powerful family from the country.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters outside the Government House in Bangkok on Monday.

item.title: The Media Equation: Where Freedom of the Press Is Muffled
item.description: China and Britain both underscore how transparency, however painful in the moment, allows democracy, business and the citizenry to thrive in the long run.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID CARR
item.media:description: Alan Rusbridger, editor of The Guardian, testifying last week.

item.title: Iraq Forces Clash With Gunmen in Syria Border Area
item.description: More than 20 people were killed in attacks in Baghdad and north of the capital, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Visiting Pakistan, Hagel Seeks to Shore Up Alliance
item.description: Chuck Hagel’s brief visit to Pakistan, the first by an American defense secretary in almost four years, came at a time of change for the country’s powerful armed forces.
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER and SALMAN MASOOD
